captions.text:
Here, I have and American Alligator. Her scientific
name is Alligator Mississippiensis. This particular

species is found in Southeastern United States,
with a large population in Florida. She is

one of two species of alligator in the world,
the other is located in China. This alligator,

specifically is only four and a half feet
long however, in their lifetime they can get

up to fourteen. With the largest recorded
being nineteen feet two inches. You can see

that her skin is covered in these rough, bony
scales called osteoderms for protection. Oh

Boy! She's a little rowdy right now, but she'll
calm down as we go along. Her nostrils are

located at the tip of her snout, which is
good for her because she can submerge her

body entirely under water and wait for prey
and still be able to breathe. At any given

moment, she has up to eighty teeth in her
mouth and because their teeth are replaceable,

she can go through about two thousand or three
thousand in her lifetime. As crocodilians

go, the male of this species are very interesting
due to his breeding habits. He's a very vocal

alligator and they call to females during
the mating season. Which is not common in

crocodilians. The female can produce clutches
of twenty to fifty eggs, and their sex determined

by temperature. Although in turtles it's usually
females are produced at hotter temperatures

and males at colder temperatures. In alligators
both cold and hot temperatures produce females

and at moderate temperatures males are produced.
Hatchlings occur in June and July and when

they hatch out they're about seven inches
long. As you can see, an alligator is an apex

predator. They're in the top of the food chain
in any environment they're in and they usually

eat anything from fish, other reptiles, amphibians,
and mammals including mice, rats, deer, and

when available cattle. You can tell an alligator
apart from a crocodile by the presence of

their rounded snout. Alligators have a rounded
snout and crocodiles have a more triangular

snout. You can also tell by their teeth. Crocodiles
have a large fourth tooth on the lower jaw

that protrudes when their mouth is closed
and alligators do not. A last interesting

fact about this particular species is that
although they're classified among the reptilia,

their closest living ancestors are actually
birds as they share common ancestors dating

back to the dinosaurs. And that is an American
Alligator.

title: Reptiles, Amphibians, Invertebrates & Small Pets : American Alligator Facts

comments.author: screeem

comments.text:
well alligators only move in short bursts of powerful energy. it's an 
adaptation. they have immense muscular power, but their body proportions 
and angles are specifically adapted for hiding in shallow water. in 
laymen's terms, they're shitty at running. they fucking suck at it. they're 
good at one thing: biting. though they are capable of walking for a few 
minutes, they typically conserve their energy. it's also a psychological 
adaptation. when threatened, they will do what they do best: react 
extremely quickly, and with extreme strength; if they fail to bite you on 
the first try, it's pretty much over. but that first snap will be very 
fast, so they often succeed. people have been killed by alligators. but 
they do not "thrash about." they are stealth animals. they snap, and then 
relax their muscles, slow their heart rate, and chill for the next 30 
minutes. by that point, they will have relaxed and grown comfortable with 
whatever human is handling them. they're really not especially violent or 
angry animals. they just happen to look vicious, but in reality they're 
pretty humane about eating prey. the nature of their mouths mean the deaths 
of their prey are quick and painless. to put it simply, there is no 
biological need for an alligator to have extensive stamina. they don't need 
to thrash about. all they need to do, 99 times out of 100, is snap and eat. 
expending more energy than that would be very wasteful. this is hard for 
humans to imagine, because our muscular strength is distributed throughout 
our bodies. alligators, on the other hand, are pretty much all jaw and 
tail. a bite from a large alligator can exert a force of over a ton. that's 
like being underneath a car, which is balanced on top of a rack of sharp 
teeth, digging directly into you. all that force takes a lot of energy. 
they're adapted for basically one strategy, and they're really good at it. 
this is how most apex predators are. it's also why apex predators are often 
the most vulnerable to extinction. have you noticed that animals at the top 
of the food chain are often endangered? they are the animals most likely to 
go extinct, throughout history. so considering that their bite takes up so 
much energy, and that's about all they're good for, they're pretty 
defenseless against a human that understands alligator physiology. a human 
that doesn't know alligators might fall prey to a small one like this, but 
a trained human? even a child could take down that gator. it's really very 
small. all you need to do is get behind it and hold down its tail and neck. 
or sit on its back. they're basically defenseless at that point. not very 
flexible creatures. you don't seem to notice it, but this woman has the 
alligator potentially pinned down. finally, if the alligator were to bite 
her, it wouldn't be likely to cause a serious injury. their teeth are 
rather dull, and they don't tear apart animals that are larger than them. 
they crush small animals in their huge mouths, and swallow them whole. 
sometimes, if the opportunity provides, they will have a feeding frenzy on 
a larger animal. but it will take them a loooong time to consume the 
animal. they can only take slow bites. crocodiles, on the other hand, have 
much sharper teeth and can pick apart larger animals more easily. so if 
this alligator managed to clamp onto her arm, for example, it wouldn't do 
any immediate damage. it would just stay clamped on, hoping it would tire 
her out. since they can hold a light grip for days, that works in the wild. 
but in this case, someone would wrangle or tazer the alligator, and it'd be 
over. she might have mildly broken skin, but no serious damage.

comments.text:
A surprising amount of people keep crocodilians without reported injury. 
American Alligators, specifically, are farmed for their hide and their meat 
in the southern US. We are generally more dangerous to them then they are 
to us. This is not a recommendation to own one, nor an underestimation of 
the care and the high cost associated with owning a pet crocodilian.

comments.text:
@ColdSideOfPillow136 Well there are basically two different types of 
Alligator's that can be kept as a "pet". One is the one you see here 
(American Alligator) and the other is the Dwarf Caiman which there are a 
couple different types of such as "Smooth Fronted" or "Cuviers". The reason 
I am pointing this out to you is because they get to be around 4-5 feet 
long and the largest one ever recorded was just over 6 feet. They are 
extremely aggressive though where as the American Alligator is less.
